Check out our voting rights guides and videos in English, Spanish, French and Arabic.

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

It's election season, which can only mean one thing — it's time to brush up on your voting rights!

Voting is the cornerstone of democracy, and it's time to vote like your rights depend on it. Go to the polls feeling confident that you know your rights, and that the ACLU has your back.

Here's what you need to know:

  • Every resident of Maine who is a U.S. citizen and is 18 or older has the right to vote — including college students who go to school here.
  • If you can't make it to the polls on Election Day, you can vote early. In-person absentee voting ends November 1.
  • You don't need an ID to vote.
  • You can register to vote on Election Day. If you are planning to register at the polls, you will need to show ID.
  • If you need help reading or marking your ballot, you can bring a friend or ask a polling official.
  • If you make a mistake, you can ask for a new ballot.
  • No one can be turned away at the polls. If you think you're eligible but you're having trouble, ask to cast a "challenged ballot."
  • Voter intimidation is illegal. If anyone tries to coerce you into voting a certain way, or not at all, tell a polling official.

Check out our one-stop shop for voting rights videos in English, Spanish, French and Arabic. Share it with your friends. Then download our voting rights guide and bring it with you!

Know Your Rights

And if you still have trouble and think your voting rights have been violated, call us at 207-774-5444.

Thanks for sticking with us,

ACLU of Maine
